4:13 got me laughing ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚
Per your own example of your mother, it is NOT normal for kids to just beat up their family members for an extended period of time. If you give them an immediate consequence the first time (I don't even believe in spanking), and don't get weak when they cry about it, they start to learn really early that it's not ok. You can't coddle a child when they're being violent. They need to know that you're angry with their behavior. You don't need to put hands on them in anger. You don't have to raise your voice. You need to be firm, put them on a step or in their room, and do it as many times as it takes for them to finally give up-- and they always do. No talking after the first time, no negotiating, just pick them up, set them down, and walk away. When they're done, ask them in a calm but firm voice, why they were put in time-out. You can help them with this part if they can't articulate it, but they'll get it nearly every time. Tell them to apologize, give them a hug, let them go play. We didn't have kids who regularly hit their parents when I was a kid. It simply wasn't tolerated. You'd stop everything to correct the behavior. No, this is a recent phenomenon.

One of the things my dad did with me when was 8 (? Donâ€™t remember the exact age) and rather aggressive, not violent but I would yell and throw insults, toward my sister and them was he took me outside got a hammer some nails and a wooden board and told me to hammer the five nails in. I started to cry and get upset because I actually hated being a nuisance to others and so the idea of disturbing our neighbours with the noise really got me. This was something my Dad knew but me made me carry through and hammer the nails. Also, instead of shouting, emotional coaching is much more effective. You need to get on your kids level and ask them how they would fee being treated that way. Ask them why they think treating you that way is acceptable. Kids don't handle emotions well at all so we have to teach them how to.  I once made my nephew sit on time out for 45 mins because he refused to apologise. He had already used the need to wee excuse once so I refused again. He purposely squeezed a pee out on the stairs. My eldest is autistic and by god does he know if he attacks someone or was naughty like this he's in deep shit. Even though special need can be a reason for bad behaviour, it is no excuse. Positive parenting does work if it's implemented right. I have never had to put my 8 year old on time out, ever. Smacking only makes your kids behave out of fear of being hit. I prefer for my kids to respect me and the boundaries.

Kids with dmdd their brain doesnâ€™t work properly. Iâ€™m not saying the kid in video has what my daughter has but normal discipline you would use on a neuro typical child doesnâ€™t work on a child with dmdd. 11:31 lol that's exactly it. I work retail, and any time you get into a public forum and start talking about how some parents really do just let their kids get away with red-blooded murder, someone's gotta come crawling out of the woodwork to boohoo about how judgmental you're being because "that child PROBABLY has a CONDITION".   And it's like, no, they probably *don't.* Obviously there are some kids who have developmental issues/conditions that cause them to act out, and it's good to be mindful of that, but the majority of the time it's because they've been taught that they can get away with bad behavior- which is sometimes blatantly obvious from how their parents interact with them.   I once literally watched a mother try to get her openly defiant (idk) 8 year-old son to come over to her, and she did it by staying right where she was and saying "Michael, come over here" about twenty times. Then her husband came over and did the *exact same thing.* I watched two grown adults become frustrated across a span of ten minutes because it didn't occur to either of them to give the instruction *once* and then walk over and do something about it when he ignored them. This kid did not have a medical condition- he had two parents without a drop of common sense between them, and he *knew* it.

I'm a big fan Daz but be careful about perpetuating harmful stereotypes about single mums. A very very small amount of women (sometimes men too) have lots of children purely to get better housing. But tories often use it to justify giving single mums with lots of kids less help and blame their struggles on themselves, rather than the lack of support and absent fathers.

As much as I do agree with him, there is always the option for abortion and if the mother choses to keep the child despite the father's opinions on wanting to get rid of it, he shouldn't be expected to give up his life because she kept the child despite him saying he didn't want it. If the roles were reverse and the father wanted the child and not the mother, everyone would have different opinions and that is where society is flawed. If she knows before the birth that the dad didn't want the child, she can do one of two things: firstly, she can get an abortion realising that she would be taking care of a child on her own and that she would struggle with that. Secondly, she could keep the baby and raise it. If she chooses the second option, that is on her. im 11 years old ğŸ˜€ğŸ˜€ğŸ˜€
I doubt I'll have kids, or will even want to for a variety of reasons. But in the off chance it happens I'll probably raise them how I was raised. If they act up you'll offer the soft punishment first (i.e., go to your room, sit on the stairs etc.), and they'll have 3 chances to do so. If they don't then they get the hard punishment (i.e., spanking, etc.).  Politeness only gets you so far, and if you only ever give soft punishments eventually the kid will stop seeing them as punishments. "Go to your room" will eventually become an excuse for a nap, etc.

True sometimes we pushed mom to the edge of her limits. For instance when she realised how bad smoking was for her health and decided to quit, she told us this straight away. Why it was bad for her and we listened, sucked it in like a sponge. She used that info as a parenting trick later on. We would be fighting again and she'd just say something like "If you won't behave I swear I'm going out and taking a long hard puff out a cigarette". We would drop it immediately and 'try to stop' her from leaving the house, even if she wasn't actively trying to walk to the door. She quit smoking in half a year from her decision and we get along quite nicely nowadays. She never hit us either. Our mom is an incredibly patient woman, I've never seen her blow a fuse but I feel like we were pretty damn close to that multiple times growing up. She's one of those mom's that bottle it up and let it all out when it counts. I love her dearly and I'm learning to say it out loud to her ğŸ¥º

Seeing this reminds me of the short story The New Mother by Lucy Clifford who was widowed with two children and quite possibly wrote the story to scare her kids into behaving properly. In the story, the kids start misbehaving and the mother warns them that if they keep at it, then she'll leave and the monstrous New Mother will take her place. Eventually, that does happen, she leaves, and New Mother appears with glass eyes and a wooden tail. The kids run from the house in fright and they stay in the forest, surviving off of berries. Their real mother never comes back and New Mother lives in the house from then on.

A child must learn consequence...even the most genetically disturbed child...all the more so. Modern psychology and liberal law has disenfranchised the authority of the typical parent...and that is part of the reason we see an increase in disturbing behaviors and more parents giving up on their children. It is why our prison population grows and more are released back into an ever growing violent society. More and more is required of the parent and less and less of the child. It is why we have so many narcissists who are also sociopaths. The discipline of fathers has died as the role is being demolished by the so-called intellectualism of liberal philosophy. Ok, time to make some people mad. The phrase "be a man" isn't toxic, sexist, offensive, what have you. It's a phrase meaning that a male needs to take up his role as the man of a number of responsibilities. In this case we have family, there has to be a man in the picture and I'm not talking literally. Even in a gay relationship or non binary, there has to be a male figure in the kid's life (especially if it's a male child) and in the spouses life because even if you have half a child it's difficult to raise them with one parent If you want to know some of the reasoning behind this you can ask my opinion on it or you can just Google it, irdc. 10:45 "There's nothing keeping me here" You are! In a well-performed Time out/Naughty-step-place, the child *will* stay put by itself. Why? Because every time the child moves from the spot, the parent put it back and start over the timer. Start this early and you won't have to do this more than a handful of times in their life, as long as you are 100% consequent. The first time you probably have to carry it back 20 times but the second time, the kid normally gets it and will stay after 5 tries to escape. Do it right and it's very effective, showing authority without causing fear or hurt.

If little kids are this bad that a parent can't control them then the parent needs to send them to behavioral therapy! I was in a behavioral therapy classes a few times as a little girl. There were two other students in the class. A boy and a girl. The girl Tia, she would through horrible tantrums so much! There was a walk in closet sized room in the classroom. She would get put in there, where there was nothing but soft pillows and beanbags and she'd be left to scream her head off as the rest of us had to ignore her and give her no attention for throwing any tantrums while in that room. I don't remember what happened to either of them, but I can remember I was afraid of Tia cause she'd scream and get all red in the face. She might have been violent I can't remember but she was so intimidating.  Funny thing is I didn't need behavioral therapy. I was well behaved. So it just might have been me being upset or something for me to get sent to behavioral therapy. But Hell, even if I was grumpy or upset towards my mom back then, I swear there's no way I was ever like Tia! Going there and experiencing Tia was so scary, I think I probably chilled out a lot more after seeing that girl go mental on tantrums!

How did he learn swear words? Its just growing in a terrible environment that has got that 4 year old kid to be so rebellious. The environment the kid is being raised in btw isn't always the parents fault. In my case it is - As a kid (I am 17 now) I was rebellious, a part of me still is and it is cause of the fact that my parents used to beat me up a lot. On one hand they would do nice things for me (grateful for that) but going ahead and beating me up...I felt it was unacceptable and I would hit them back, at times they would also kick me out of the house. The beating up was mainly for academics which I was never bad at (I am talking 85-95% results every semester), which my parents now take credit for though they didn't do shit (kinda funny considering their academics prowess is absolutely ridiculous and the teachers who I have "learnt" from I never understood, I self study to this day not paying attention to a single class). I was also rebellious cause my parents were wrong in most cases beating me up (they still are wrong, not beating me up anymore but I'm moving out soon so I couldn't care less), that pain and anger all went back to them. Also my dad used to cuss a lot at me too, he still does. To this day I haven't cussed at anyone irl other than my parents cause I know how much pain one goes through hearing such hurtful words.  The ones who go through such pain become good parents later on in life if they know what empathy is. Not saying I will be a good parent in future but rather I would try harder and better instead of losing my patience.   I'm guessing no one ever will have enough time or could care to read this comment (cause yea I see it as a load of crap too ğŸ˜‚) but I wanted to share my feelings so here it is anyway.
I grew up in a west Indian family. I acted like this, I got hit. Hard.

Honestly, kids need structure and discipline and are so much happier with it, because they want clear communication too!  A lot of parents will just threaten a punishment and never act on it.  It confuses them.  Also, if they're acting out they need punishment, they need to be shown harming others is not okay and has consequences.  They don't have to be physical.  It's usually something as simple as not being able to go somewhere they want, or have a candy they want or a toy.    She lets them run all over her!!!  I hope they're doing well now.
